content.webTitle: Broadchurch recap: series two, episode three

fields.headline: Broadchurch recap: series two, episode three
fields.bodyText: Spoiler alert: this blog is for people watching Broadchurch 2. Don’t read on if you haven’t seen series two episode three. Read Vicky Frost’s recap of episode two here The Latimer trial Quite a lot has been written about procedural inconsistencies in Broadchurch’s court scenes – and there will doubtless be some views about whether DS Miller would be made to testify against her husband. (I had been wondering about this very thing.) But for dramatic reasons, we had to see Ellie tell her side of the story: pleading across court to her former best friends; putting her love for Joe firmly in the past tense. Whenever you start to doubt Broadchurch, Olivia Colman arrives on screen, and reminds you what makes it so compelling. Her performance on the witness stand would have convinced me, at any rate. I know I mentioned this last week, but it’s worth repeating. Colman playing against Eve Myles is great to watch. The actors seem to bring out the best in each other: their (almost) burgeoning friendship has a real joy to it, even if Claire is lying through her teeth and Ellie is trying to trap her into revealing the truth. In other circumstances, you feel as if they really could have been been friends. Miller is doing her best, of course, to maintain some friendship with the Latimers. Beth, however, even with waters breaking, contractions getting more frequent, and nobody else to help, would rather never see her former friend again. But possibly this second series of Broadchurch is missing the opportunity to sit with that situation for a little while, and explore it. We’re seeing increasingly less of those relationships that tie a community together. I’m sure Sharon’s imprisoned son, Jocelyn’s car accident, and her inability to pay for her mother’s care will all prove to be important. But what with Beth giving birth, Ellie trying to get over Joe with rubbish drunk sex, and Sandbrook, of course, it feels as if everyday interaction between the town’s residents and their families is suffering at the hands of plot. That moment between Chloe and Ellie on the stairs while Beth was in labour was great, while the exchange between Mark and the vicar was sharp, too. More of them, please. Sandbrook If last week’s meeting between Lee and Claire that had them escaping out of a window wasn’t frustrating enough, this week’s conclusion of the cliffhanger – they just went back to Claire’s house after finding the not-very-well-hidden cameras – was more so. Writer Chris Chibnall clearly wanted to give Lee a complaint about Alec that would lead to an apology and introduce an element of doubt over Claire’s relationship with her ex-husband, but surely there were less melodramatic ways to get there. If Chibnall had wanted to reinvestigate Sandbrook, I find myself wishing he had dedicated this series to doing just that. I understand the dramatic strength of having Ellie and Claire treading similar paths but with very different stories behind them – so the suggestion in court that it could have been Ellie emailing from Joe’s computer, for instance, underlines Hardy’s question about the pendent – but as it is, we’re cycling through possibilities and suspects in this case, without actually knowing anything much about the crime. So Lee, super-cocky in his vest and roll-up, brandishing a giant sledgehammer, makes Hardy say sorry and then turns up at the detective’s house with a big old file of paperwork on possible suspects the Gillespies to prove his innocence. Claire, meanwhile, with her inconsistent stories and mystery bluebell, is recast not as a witness in protection, but a suspect in danger of absconding. Which feels a clever twist – along with Hardy getting Miller to see if she independently came to the same conclusion – but we’ve got there in three episodes in which Sandbrook hasn’t even been the main focus. I’m dying for the show to take a bit of a breath and calm itself down a little. Score watch No wonder Ellie was shouting at the court by the end of the episode. It was the only way she could make herself heard. Thoughts and observations • This courtroom exchange was great, even if the judge didn’t think so: “How was your sex life?” “I don’t know, how would you describe yours?” “Not frequent enough, to be honest.” • Can you get bluebells in France? Yes. Here’s a handy guide to bluebells of the world for you. • If Hardy had realised the suspect might be Claire not Lee, why was he so worried about her safety that he made Miller hand over her car? Or was it simply that Claire had done a runner? (Which she could surely do all the time he’s at work?) • A urine test for Rohypnol can be effective up to 60 hours after the drug is ingested – presumably if Claire had given the police this version of events at the time they would have been able to check its veracity. • It looked as if Hardy’s dangerous health condition had mysteriously cleared up. But apparently not. • In case you didn’t see Mark Lawson’s piece on whether the current Broadchurch backlash is justified, you can read it here.
